headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Welcome to the Avago Technologies Limited Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Jacob Sayer, Vice President of Business Development and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; Doug Bettinger, Chief Financial Officer of Avago Technologies. 
After the market closed today, Avago distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the second quarter of fiscal year 2011. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors Section of Avago's website. 
This conference call is being webcast live and recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived on the Investors section of our website at www.avagotech.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Doug will be providing details of our Q2 financial year 2011 results, background to our Q3 outlook, and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Avago reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results.
Please also refer to the press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that may affect our business and that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Jacob. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to start today by reviewing some of the recent business highlights, and then Doug will provide summary of second quarter financial results. 
As you may have seen from our earnings announcement earlier today, both revenue and earnings for the quarter of fiscal second quarter 2011 were at the top of our guidance, with net revenue up 2% from the preceding quarter and up 9% year-on-year from second quarter of 2010. 
Now there's little doubt that the catastrophic events in Japan have and will continue to impact the global economy, especially for the electronics and semiconductor supply chain. Thankfully, it appears to date that our own business has been impacted only in minor ways by these events, a lengthy and ongoing review of our supply-chain has identified no critical material shortages that we haven't been able to manage around. 
So stepping back despite these events we see global demand for our products to be improving. Most OEM customers are continuing to grow and have worked through most of the inventory buildup that occurred late in 2010, and most of this work through would have been finished by the end of last quarter. Accordingly, from our view, demand for products appears poised for sustained growth for the balance of the year on top of normal seasonality.
Now within our wireless communications target market, as background, we manufactured FBAR duplexers, power amplifiers, light and proximity sensors, and optical navigation devices for feature reach in smart mobile phones. We also manufacture RF components for the wireless base station market.
Sales from our Wireless Communications Target market represented 36% of our second quarter revenue, our revenue from this market remains flat from Q1, but only rose 3% above Q2 last year. This performance was roughly in line with our expectations for the quarter and in line with normal seasonal trends for us. During the quarter, we were excited to see the launch of the first smartphone utilizing a 4G/LTE Band, a category of devices that we believe will include considerable RF content from Avago, given the strength of our FBAR filter and power amplifying lineup. During this quarter, 19 new handset and tablet platforms were launched with our components. 
Now looking ahead to the third quarter of fiscal 2011, we still expect the launch of several Next Generation phones, utilizing 4G wireless capabilities. We anticipate revenue in this target market -- we anticipate that revenue in this target market will get a shot in the arm and increase in the high single to low double-digit percentage points. As you will all recall, the second half of the year is also seasonally strong for wireless end markets.
Within our wired communication infrastructure markets, you may recall we design high-speed SerDes ASICs and manufacture optical transceivers for enterprise networking, data center switching, and high-speed computing applications. Compared with Q2 last year, our revenue from this end market grew 30%. Our sales from the Wired Infrastructure market grew 5% sequentially over Q1, and accounted for 29% of our total Q2 sales. 
Revenues from Wired Infrastructure grew better than we had expected at the beginning of the quarter. We saw strong demand from our proprietary 25G and 50G gigabit per second parallel optics using core routing as carriers invested heavily to expand backhaul capacity. During the quarter, we also ramped our 12 channel 120G proprietary transmitter receiver modules to major supercomputing OEMs.
This growth from our Fiber-Optic Transceiver business was offset partially somewhat by temporary weakness in our ASIC business, caused by customer inventory adjustments in data networking. Nonetheless, we expect growth in the ASIC business to resume in this coming quarter. Thus looking forward to Q3, we believe revenues from the overall wired infrastructure target market will continue to grow in the low to mid-single-digit percentage points quarter-on-quarter.
Turning to industrial. We manufacture, as you know, and sell optocouplers, motion encoders, and industrial fiber for various server drives, factory automation, and power generation and distribution. Net revenue from this target market grew 1%, compared to that of the prior quarter. The end market grew 14% from the same quarter a year ago, and accounted for 30% of our Q2 2011 net revenue.
Now net inventory adjustment in the supply chain here seems to have run their course. The recovery of developed economies, as well as sustaining industrialization of emerging economies like China, have driven very robust resales growth 7% quarter-on-quarter by our distributors during this quarter. Notwithstanding, we continue to manage inventory in the channels very tightly. Consequently, we expect to see mid-single-digit revenue growth in Q3. 
In our Consumer and Computing Peripherals market, our smaller segment, we manufactured navigation sensors for optical mice, motion sensors for printers, and reflective encoders used in optical disk drives. Revenues from these target market increase 3% from the preceding quarter. On the other hand, year on year, revenue shrunk 38% and represents today, only 5% of our second quarter results. 
During this seasonally soft period, the market for PCs and printers remain subdued and we continue to experience inventory correction in our supply chain for optical disk drive.
With this color as background -- I'm sorry, however, we do believe we will see a seasonal uptick in demand due to the remaining portion of the year. And consequently, we estimate our Q2 revenue from consumer to increase above mid-to-high-single digit percentage points compared to Q2.
Now with all this background, looking forward to Q3, after weak first half, we expect wireless to return to being a major growth driver on the back of multiple next-generation smartphone launches happening now in fact. Revenue from our industrial and wired infrastructure target market should continue to show moderate, stable growth, building on solid performance during Q2. 
In sum, we expect to see our revenue Q3 2011 to increase between 5% to 8% over last quarter. With that summary, let me now turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of our second quarter fiscal results. Doug?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext:
Thanks, Hock. Good afternoon to everyone. Before reviewing the second quarter fiscal 2011 financial results, I want to remind you that as always my comments today will focus primarily on the non-GAAP results. Reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release we issued earlier today, and is also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Revenue of $560 million in Q2 represents an increase of 2% from last quarter, and an increase of 9% versus the same quarter of last year. And as Hock reviewed, the sequential increase was as we expected at the beginning of the quarter, although revenue from our Wired Networking target market was stronger than we expected, and revenue from our consumer and computing target market was a little bit weaker.  Resales from our distribution partners grew sequentially in Q2. 
At the end of Q2, distribution inventory was at a level consistent with the prior quarter in dollars, and it was actually down in terms of days on hand. We remain very comfortable with the level of inventory that we're holding in distribution.
Q2 gross margin was 51.8%. This was down about 20 basis points from Q1 primarily due to product mix. Growth in our Wired target market, and to a lesser extent, our Consumer target market as compared to our higher margin industrial market brought gross margin down a little bit.
During the quarter, R&D expenses increased $3 million sequentially to $73 million. SG&A also increased by $3 million to $50 million. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 13% and SG&A remained at 9% of revenue. Income from operations decreased by $2 million sequentially to $167 million, and represented 30% of net revenue. Q2 income from operations compares with income from operations of $169 million last quarter, and was $135 million in Q2 of last year. And I'd like to point out from Q2 2010 to Q2 2011, revenue has increased by 9%, while income from operations has increased 24%.
Taxes for Q2 were lower than I expected and they came in at $2 million. Essentially, we generated a higher percentage of income this quarter and more tax efficient jurisdictions. These results translated into net income of $165 million, which is the same as it was last quarter. Q2 earnings per diluted share of $0.64, compares with $0.65 in Q1 due to a slight increase in share count. 
Net income in Q2 of 2010 was $117 million or $0.47 per diluted share. Total share base compensation in Q2 was $9 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q2 includes $1 million in cost of goods sold, $3 million in R&D, and $5 million in SG&A. 
In Q3, we anticipate share base compensation will be approximately $12 million. This increase is the result of new restricted shares and options granted to employees during Q2. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense.
So now let me turn to the balance sheet. I'm pleased with the performance of our team here this quarter. Days sales outstanding was 47 days. This was 1 day lower than last quarter. Inventory came in at $194 million and that's down 4% from last quarter. This translated to days on hand of 65 days. And this is down 5 days from last quarter, and is consistent with the midpoint of our inventory model. 
At the end of the second quarter, our cash balance was $596 million. The primary change in cash came from $251 million of cash that we generated from operations. In particular, our management of working capital was very strong in Q2. Capital expenditures in Q2 were $19 million and that's compared with $32 million last quarter. Quarter-to-quarter capital expenditures fluctuated due to the timing of deliveries of equipment and assets. Our expectation of CapEx for Q3 is in the range of $20 million to $25 million. And on March 30, 2011, we paid an interim dividend of $0.08 per ordinary share, which consumed $20 million of cash. This dividend was raised $0.01 from the prior quarter.
Now let me review the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2011. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance.
As Hock told you, revenue is expected to be up 5% to 8% sequentially reflecting strong seasonality in wireless as well as growth in both our consumer and industrial target markets. Gross margin is expected to be 51.75% plus or minus 75 basis points. I expect operating expenses to be about $132 million. This is up due to certain selected areas of our expansion within the business, especially new R&D programs, some increases in litigation expenses, as well as increases in employee compensation consistent with our annual salary review cycle.
I expect interest and other to be approximately 0. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $4 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 258 million shares. 
And so let me summarize, during Q2 we generated revenue at the top-end of our expectations and essentially maintained margins near record levels. Heading into the third quarter, we see strong seasonality coming from our wireless target market.
In addition, we expect growth from both our consumer and industrial target markets. The management team here continues to remain committed to driving the business towards our long-term business model. 
And that concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open the call for questions at this time.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: T first one relates to the wireless outlook. It sounds like, in your guidance, you're expecting sort of normal wireless seasonality. I wanted to understand a little bit longer term. headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: And then if I could ask my follow-up, my follow-up is regarding gross margin. It seems like maybe by taking inventory down a little bit this quarter that may have been a gross margin headwind. I was wondering a little bit longer term, what are the main drivers to gross margin, what sort of a natural gross margin target over the next several years and perhaps if you could give us an update on the mix of proprietary versus non-proprietary products.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Growth, the biggest, single biggest, by far, overwhelming driver to our gross margin is our product mix. It's really our product mix and the product mix relates to the level of proprietary products versus more standard, non-legacy, non-proprietary products. That all has been and continues to be the biggest driver. Inventory movement does vary a little and the reason for that, Terence, is our entire back-end and a lot of when we use silicon is all outsourced. What we have insource are really proprietary 3.5(GHz) processors. And while important as a percent of cost of goods sold, they don't represent such a big percentage of our overall cost of goods sold. So it's really coming down to given how variable our cost of goods sold is. It is really all about product mix and proprietary and the level of proprietary fiber and the level of proprietary product, and the level of proprietary product because thing it's about time. It's a percentage we have been changing, moving up since 5 years back. We're now at a level of in the high 40s%, 50%. Now it's not over a year as we go through each quarter. There's obviously -- it's a bit hard to predict precisely what it is, but it does have a minor, some minor impact as we see this quarter on the overall gross margin. And we can bounce back up or more than bounce back up the following quarter. And you can see that from the way we guide our gross margin numbers. So it's easier for me to tell you probably year-on-year next year, what's likely to be that for me to tell you this quarter, versus next quarter, versus last quarter what a precise gross margin would be. But we kind of know where the last general level of it is overall. So to cut the long story short, we've guided -- we have used a long-term model on gross margin, which we have been able to keep to pretty reasonably, accurately that we would grow our gross margin in the range of 100 to 150 basis points each year.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Right and just to remind you, in terms of the gross margin model we put out at the Analyst Day at the end of last year was 50% to 53%.  So we're trending where we want to be in those ranges.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Doug, on OpEx, how much of the OpEx increase this quarter would you consider to be a onetime step up?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Well, in terms of Q2, we came up pretty much where I thought we would rather. I think we had guided the $124 million, we came out at $123 million. So there really isn't too much that's onetime in...

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: The July quarter -- really what's happening is we're investing more substantially in R&D. It's what's driving this. And I don't think that's onetime, Romit. We just haven't been able to keep R&D spending -- R&D hasn't been able to keep pace with the revenue growth. And we have a model that we're trying to manage a company here to in terms of kind of call it 13% to 14% R&D to generate the future growth that we want. So we've been trying to get that caught back up.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: But touching on this R&D issue that Doug talks about, Romit, is why we decide to put in more money into R&D now is there's just so many opportunities we see out there. And basically, we're putting more into R&D with the view that it would accelerate our growth even more. It's just simply because the opportunities especially in wireless, as well as wired infrastructure.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Hock, just one last question for you. Q2 was a tough quarter for a lot of optical companies. And at the same time, your Wired Infrastructure business was pretty stable, in fact I think it was a little bit better than you had guided. Could you help us reconcile?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Yes. See, we don't compete in the same space of, necessarily, in all the same spaces as some of what I deem are typical fiber competitors. I mean, one we say we focus very much on enterprise very much so. But there's a core group of products which are very, very proprietary and very, very unique in the sense of they kind of bridge between transport and Enterprise Network. I'm talking for instances one big area we got a lot of benefit of in Q2 was those parallel optic, high bandwidth optic fibers that goes very importantly into the core routers, the core routing and H-routing environment that is used a lot in wireless infrastructure backhaul. As obviously, the carriers were investing a lot, and we've been seeing a lot of up demand for those products, not just in North America, even in China. And then we also, as I mentioned ramp up delivery in Q2, in a major significant way into those fairly unique inter-fiber, interconnects chip-on-chip for the next-generation supercomputers that Big Blue push out. And that also made a fairly significant addition to our Fiber Optics business.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis from Barclays Capital.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Hock, just to clarify the ramp that you're seeing, you said 4G, were you just talking about the HSP plus stuff or LTEs?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: We're talking about the real 4G, and including WiMAX.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: And then when you look at -- you've had an advantage in bins too when you look at LTE, do you see that in certain bins having the same sort of advantage for you guys with your FBAR.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: In a different manner. I mean, for instance, a lot of the LTE -- LTE is a lot very much favorable towards data and, but a lot of phones also need to have simultaneous voice as well. And so, when you start running in to do both, you start having a lot of RF from a content which leads to the issue of coexistence more and more, and we stand to get a favor as because of FBAR technology. So yes, you're right, to answer your question directly, we see 4G increasing a lot of potential opportunities in content for technologies and products.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: And then just finally, I was trying to the strength that you saw on the parallel optics, is there any way that you can quantify, or not precise numbers obviously, but just kind of give some sort of scale as to where that kind of business is and where can it go.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Well, the way it can go plenty of places because there's a lot of opportunity next-generation systems come to play for instance in data centers. You're talking about a lot, a lot of very high bandwidth, very low, very high density interconnect that needed to go from say supplied service to top of direct switches and aggregating it all in very tight spaces. Basically you need very high bandwidth interconnect transceivers that is at the same time these transceivers have to take low-power and do not create a lot of emissions to interfere with each other signal integrity so to speak. What it comes down to is fiber optics. So we're seeing a lot of that, we're seeing an increasing amount of that. Where that will grow? We obviously think this is a business by itself on proprietary large fiber-optic and parallel optics, large bandwidth fiber optics. That could grow from where we are today, and where we are today, it's roughly about, I would say 20%, 25% of our entire Wired Infrastructure business, 20% to 25% of Wire Infrastructure business. And is a business that we see that can grow much faster than normal Wired Communication business. Talking about at least 2x, 3x that rate.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Also, there's been talk especially from some of distributors that the industry market in particular that growth has resumed in some of the developed geographies. Now you've traditionally talked about your strength in emerging economies. Can you quantify for us what the relative growth rates are between the developed economies versus the emerging economies, especially on the industrial and market front?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 24, 2011
componenttext: Yes. I assume your question really relates to industrial, and most of our Industrial businesses as you know go through distributors. So it relates to what you're saying. You may have missed an earlier remark I made, but in Q2 last quarter, our global distributor resale, which is all mainly industrial, largely industrial, grew sequentially 7% actually. Even though our -- and you know we recognize revenue on a shipping basis. We grew our revenue industrial just about 1%. But our resale, the resale numbers are industrial, on our distributors grew closer to 7% sequentially. So that there indicator in fact of a resumption as you correctly pointed out of growth not in developed economies globally. Not just something pulled along by emerging economies like China, industrializing themselves. As to why there's a differential absolutely it's hard to measure the 2 because the fact is a lot of our customers in Japan, Europe, exports into emerging economies. So it's really hard to say, to have any meaningful comparison to say what does industrial developed economies versus developing economies, what is the difference between the two in terms of your growth rate because a big part of, for instance, Central Europe's industrial growth that we see today are through large OEMs who export systems, huge systems, to China. As is the case in Japan too. In fact that's a big engine in countries like China, Brazil are big engines of growth for the industrial powerhouses of Europe and Japan. So it might not be that meaningful if I give you data but just enough to say that our resale in places like China is at a much higher trajectory than our resale growth in say, Europe or in Japan.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Jacob. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to start today by reviewing some of the recent business highlights, then Doug will provide summary of the first quarter financial results. 
Now as you may have seen from our earnings announcement just released, revenue for the quarter was seasonally down, as expected, with net revenue down 4% from the last quarter but up 21% year-on-year from the first quarter 2010. Now during the past year, calendar 2010 in particular, we had seen semiconductor companies grow faster than their end markets. However, by late 2010, rising inventory levels at OEMs and distributors caused the industry to slow production in order to bring supply more in line with end market demand. Now we are not entirely immune from these micro trends, and we expect our revenue and the semiconductor industry's revenue growth to more closely align with the end market demand for calendar 2011. Fortunately, our wire end markets have continued to grow but at a more moderate pace than in the prior year. In the near term, however, our revenue is expected to be impacted by an inventory adjustment in the OEM and distribution supply chain and, as was the case this quarter, the return of normal seasonal selling patterns. Having said all this, we saw strong quarter-on-quarter growth in our wired networking business, driven largely by increased sales of proprietary parallel optical transceivers using enterprise and data center networking applications as well as high-speed computing applications. 
So start -- another thing to note before I get into commentary on how our various businesses are doing is that starting with this quarter's commentary, I won't dispense with providing specific color on trends in each of our 4 target markets. I will instead provide further information on our own performance within those targeted markets. 
Beginning with wireless communication target markets. Now as you know, we manufacture duplexes, power amplifiers and Optical Finger Navigation devices for feature-rich and smartphones. We also manufacture RF components for wireless base stations. Now sales from our wireless communication markets represented 37% of our first quarter revenues, and our revenue from this target market fell 8% from there of the preceding quarter, Q4 fiscal '10 and -- but rose 17% above the same quarter a year ago. This performance on my --- was roughly in line with our expectations for the quarter, better than normal seasonal trends we have observed in the past.
Normally, OEM demand in this market rose over late November and December. This year, we did not really experience a slackening in demand until January. Additionally, we experienced favorable product mix, we saw stable pricing in the quarter, better than we would normally expect for first quarter. And during this same -- this quarter, our parts were designed into over 20 new smartphones and tablet platforms on major OEMs worldwide. Now looking ahead to this second quarter fiscal 2011, we anticipate revenue in this targeted market to remain largely flat, in line with difficult seasonal patterns. 
In wired infrastructure, we design high-speed SerDes-based ASICs and as well as manufacture optical transceivers for enterprise networking, data center switching, high-speed computing applications. Compared with Q1 last year, our revenue from this end market grew 27%. Our sales from this wired networking market grew 7% sequentially over that of the preceding quarter and accounted for 28% of our total Q1 sales. 
Revenue from this market grew better than we expected at the start of the quarter. We saw strong demand for our proprietary parallel optics using high end unified computing environments. During the quarter, we experienced an improved demand for our proprietary 25G and 50G parallel optics using call routing infrastructure, and we have began shipping the 12-channel and 20G proprietary transceivers to a major supercomputing customer. We also saw strength from 1-gigabit per second and 10-gigabit per second migrations and from 8 gigs storage optical transceivers. In the meantime, I should add our market share in supplying our SerDes-based ASICs to major enterprise, networking and computing OEMs continue to grow. Consequently, we expect revenue from this target market to be able to sustain growth in the low single digits quarter-on-quarter sequentially, which expect over the rest of this year. In industrial and automotive electronics, we manufacture and sell optocouplers used in electrical isolation, motion encoders used in industry control and industrial fiber optics used for data communication in harsh factory environments. Net revenue from this target market decreased 3% from the prior quarter. This end market grew 42% from the same quarter a year ago and accounted for 30% of our Q1 2011 revenues. 
Despite holiday shutdowns during this quarter, resale of our industrial products held up well in all geographical markets as exports to emerging economies supported demand in Europe and Japan while the Americas showed some recovery. Having said this, significant inventory adjustments in distribution channels and OEMs reduced shipment revenue sequentially in Q1 as compared to Q4 and will likely keep revenue flat in this current Q2 quarter despite expected resale improvements.
In our consumer and computing peripheral market, we manufacture navigation sensors for optical mice, motion sensors for printers and reflective encoders using optical disk drives. Revenue from this target end market declined 26% sequentially on a year-on-year basis. Our revenue from this market has shrunk by 36% and now only represents 5% of our first quarter 2011 sales. During this quarter, revenue from optical mice and the printers experienced weaker-than-normal seasonality, reflecting generally weaker PC and consumer demand. Now with respect to optical disk drives, however, we saw significant inventory adjustments as our OEM customers had accumulated inventory in a weakened environment during calendar '10. While we foresee end demand to now remain flat for Q2, we currently estimate that our revenue from this market will increase in the high single to low double digits percentage points as compared to Q1 with the completion of investment within this end market and given our expectations for recovery in demand for our components.
So to sum up, while substantial follow-up business is tied to general market conditions, we believe with the -- we are seeing significant market share growth due to the launch of proprietary solutions. As we move forward, we see we are ramping our high-bandwidth embedded fiber optics in high-performance computing applications. Our SerDes-based ASICs are very well positioned with major OEMs in the next-generation data center switching that you see have been announced today. In smartphones, we are securing major design wins that will give us very strong momentum into the second half of 2011. For 2000 -- for Q1, we have seen our bookings sustained, continuing so far into fiscal Q2. We accordingly expect to see revenue in Q2 to be in the range of perhaps a downside of 1% and, on the upside, we could be up as much as 2% over that of the last quarter. With that, let me turn this call over to Doug.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Hock. And good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for being on the call. Before reviewing the first quarter of fiscal 2011 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today, as they always do, will focus primarily on the non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release we issued today and is also on our website at avagotech.com. 
Revenue of $550 million in Q1 represents a decrease of 4% from last quarter and an increase of 21% versus the same quarter a year ago. And as Hock reviewed, the sequential decline was maybe a little bit better than we expected at the beginning of the quarter really due to the strength of our revenue in the wired network end target market. 
Resales from our distribution partners were down modestly in Q1. Adjusting for the normal holiday effect in the quarter would have resales fairly flat. 
At the end of Q1, distribution inventory was at a level that was roughly consistent with the prior quarter. We remain well within our inventory model and are comfortable with the amount of inventory that we have in distribution today. 
Q1 gross margin was 52%. This represents a new record gross margin percentage for the company. Gross margin was up sequentially from Q4 and was better than our expectations for the quarter due to a beneficial product mix as well as strong NRE [ph] revenues at our ASICs business. 
During the quarter, R&D expenses increased by $2 million sequentially to $70 million. SG&A decreased by $1 million to $47 million. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 13% and SG&A rounded up to 9% of net revenues this quarter. Operating expenses came in $2 million to $3 million lower than we expected at the beginning of the quarter really due to a onetime reversal of bonus accruals. 
Income from operations decreased by $2 million sequentially to $169 million, but it actually increased to 31% of net revenue. Q1 income from operations compares with income from operations of $171 million last quarter and with $104 million in Q1 of last year. But I should point out, from Q1 of 2010 to Q1 of 2011, revenue has increased 21% while income from operations has increased 63%. Taxes for Q1 were lower than we expected and came in at $1 million primarily due to the reinstatement of U.S. R&D tax credits.
These results translate into the net income of $165 million or $0.65 per diluted share. This net income compares with net income of $190 million or $0.76 per diluted share in Q4 and with net income of $88 million or $0.36 per diluted share in Q1 of 2010. And just a reminder, net income last quarter, Q4 of 2010, included a $28.7 million discrete tax benefit related to our debt reduction, which equated to roughly $0.11 per diluted share. 
Total share-based compensation in Q1 was $7 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q1 includes $1 million in cost of goods sold, $3 million in R&D and $3 million in SG&A. In Q2, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $8 million. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income continues to exclude share-based compensation expense. 
So now, turning to the balance sheet. I have to admit I'm a little disappointed by our performance through this quarter. Days sales outstanding came in at 48 days, and this was 3 days higher than the prior quarter due to the linearity of sales in the quarter. Inventory came in at $203 million, which was up 7% from last quarter. This translated to days on hand of 70 days. This is up 9 days from Q4 and is at the high end of our desired model. We intend to manage this inventory lower next quarter, and I expect it to be down several days from where it is this quarter. 
At the end of the first quarter, our cash balance was $363 million. The changes in cash included $67 million in cash from operations and $230 million used to redeem the notional amount of our remaining debt. I should point out that cash used in operations in Q1 included our annual bonus payments of $37 million, a $14 million call premium related to our debt redemptions and $40 million in final interest payments. And Q1 is typically our lowest cash generating quarter. 
Capital expenditures in Q1 came in at $32 million, and this compares with $30 million last quarter. Our expectations for CapEx in Q2 is a range of $23 million to $28 million. We also spent $8 million during Q1 to acquire a small motion encoder chip company in the U.S. to complement our portfolio of industrial and automotive electronics businesses. The financial impact of this acquisition will be immaterial to our financial results for the year.
Now let's review the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the second quarter of fiscal 2011. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we don't intend to update this guidance.
Revenue is expected to be in the range of down 1% to up 2% sequentially, which is consistent with normal seasonal patterns for this quarter. Gross margin is expected to be 52% plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be $124 million. This is up due to the timing of spending on new R&D projects. Interest and other is expected to be approximately 0, and I should point out this excludes $1 million of expense from the anticipated replacement of our outstanding revolving credit facility. Taxes are forecasted to be $4 million. And finally, the share count forecast is for 256 million shares. 
So let me summarize. During Q1, we generated revenue a little bit better than we expected. We achieved record gross margin of 52% and operating margin of 31%. Our improvement here is primarily the result of an improving product mix. Heading into the second quarter, we see a continuation of normal seasonal patterns. We remain encouraged by the designing momentum in our wireless and wired target markets. The management team here continues to remain committed to driving the business towards our long-term business model. And that concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, would you please open the call up for questions at this time?

We also see obviously improved -- improvement in developed economies in Central Europe, in North -- in Americas, and those are the drivers of why we say -- why I say industrial demand continues to be growing. Not at a fast rate but at a very stable, measured rate.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

And you probably may be aware that the LTE that's coming out in North America, the first at 700 megahertz approximately, LTE is right next to the public safety radio band. So the possibility of co-existence is very real there. Co-existence means one band interfering with the other. For instance, your phone crossing over to somewhere else into the other band, which might interfere with. But, of course, very sensitive is the public safety radio band. And therefore, the likelihood of FBAR coming in for that kind of band will -- is very rare just to avoid interference and to improve signal quality.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. Any way to quantify how much of an inventory drawdown you think is going on with your customers right now? The differential between those 2?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: John, that -- it's very hard to quantify that because it's not across the whole world that we see that, all right? As you know, in Asia Pacific, the lies of that -- the data is more suspect in those areas. And that's a big growing portion. In fact, that's the largest growing region of our sales universe. So it's very hard to quantify that accurately. But the sense we have is, yes, we're going through them, and one I call inventory adjustments, which is ship-outs, is probably going faster than ship-ins. But also, don't forget another big part of inventory. It sits at OEMs, contract manufacturers and Os. And in calendar '10, those guys, because of the fear of shortages of key components, have also stocked up their share of components, which they have been working down over the past, I would say, 4, 5 months.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: And then, Hock, when we think about the growth rate for that segment, if you look in the January quarter, which was an inventory correction quarter, you still grew 41% year-over-year off of our compare, which at the time was an all-time peak. And so I'm just kind of curious, as you think about some of the new applications in that market, what's your view of kind of the new Avago growth rate in the industrial and automotive cause that sector has been leading year-over-year growth now, I think, for 4 quarters consecutively?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, I know. And a big part of why they -- 2 reasons why those 2 are or why this is happening, one is, in one -- one is emerging economies, places like China, are just spending enormous amount of money upgrading infrastructure, and we are very, very in infrastructure especially as it relates to -- see, I think in the case of China, at the beginning, while some of -- when you talk infrastructure, that's about power, power, power. And we do a lot of products and I like to call isolation, optical isolation that goes into power generation and power conversion. Since then, from power, we ventured into transportation. And then, the -- China and their cost of labor is going up, labor laws are putting in place -- they're putting in place some very strict -- so factories are automating in China, believe it or not. Your little mom-and-pop shops in China are even automating. And we sell our different set of products into factory automation. So that's like the second round of kicking. Then we -- of course, we -- while all this was going on, we have this additional new business that we talked about, which is basically renewable or alternative energies: solar, wind, other things, even nuclear. And we sell more and more components in that. So this 41% growth rate is selling to a different set -- an increased set of end markets than we saw in 2008, say, or 2009. And that's why you see a 41% that's -- growth year-on-year. That seems to be sustainable. And they're showing no signs of going -- heading the other way like it did in 2009. It is sustainable. It's holding out. How long will it hold up? My view of it is more than a year, definitely. Definitely more than a couple of years because there are more new -- there are new opportunities. Another area of sustainable growth, we think, is -- in renewable energy is automotive. All these electric cars, hybrid cars, no doubt they are still small in quantities, but they're buying a lot of components in its power generation, in the conversion of battery power to driving basically -- or driving those automobiles, those transportations. They use a lot more of those components than the current vehicle we see here today. And that's also a growing, increasing opportunity for our industrial products.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: And then, Hock, my last question. I think I understand the opportunity for you guys in smartphones. Can you help me understand? As the tablet market starts to ramp here, what kind of opportunity do you guys have in that new market?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: Well, in many ways, similar because most of these tablets are coming with wireless connections, as is the iPad. They're coming -- wireless connections. And the wireless connection they are putting in are getting more -- not less but more sophisticated. I mean, I could see a path towards LTE coming in because LTE is for data and tablet is really data. You don't put or you don't -- it's very hard to stick a tablet on your ear and the same on your head. So we see that opportunity exist in so many ways similar to what we see in smartphones. Is this coming from the PC side perhaps as opposed from the phone side but coming to the same converging area, which is wireless data transfer, which means they needs a lot of RF front end in terms of duplexers, filters and power amplifiers. So we see them as increased set of new opportunities for us.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: With regard to handset growth over the next several years, what are really the drivers of incremental dollars? Or might it also be conversion of, let's say, Chinese base of 2G, 2.5G phones, which are probably 600 million units per year? As they convert to 3G, is that conversion from Chinese 2G to 3G, is that requiring FBAR filters?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: And that's a very good question. If I look at it over the next 3 years, yes. First and foremost, as you know, Terence, we are very much focused only on smartphones. So for us, smartphones, we believe, is an area -- is an opportunity that continues to grow faster than the overall handset markets. As you correctly call -- pointed out, 2Gs will move to 3Gs and more. So that will have a -- and so that will be a big driver. On top of that, smartphones, as you know, the driver towards it is they're getting -- they are pushing it in smartphones that work over multiple carriers, multiple regions, multiple modes, so to speak. So you're ending up with multimode, multi-band sets across various carriers across various geographies. You want a phone that works in Japan, that works in the U.S., which works in China. And so what you do is you start putting in more content into those phones and including Wi-Fi. And as you put in more bands, the bands start to run very close to each other, a comment I made earlier. Then you create a phenomenon called co-existence. When too many bands are operating close to each other, they tend to interfere, cross-talk, so to speak. And the way to avoid it is to put in on FBAR. So there's great demand for FBAR. But as you move from 3G to LTE, you start to put more and more content. And the most interesting thing is, one of the phones that has come out in the U.S, one of the first 4G phones in Sprint has $6 of content of our products in it. That's an example of what an LTE phone gets you to.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011

As far as FBAR is concerned, which by the way is our term for BAWR, which is Bulk Acoustic -- a generic term for Bulk Acoustic Wave Resonators. I mean, what we have done is we have produced billions and billions of units of those parts. And really, the -- we do not see much competition truly in the area of BAWR. But SAW is still a real competitor. SAW filters.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2011
componenttext: Also, in the past, Avago has used its data in BAWR to add more gas content in the form of PA-duplexers. Does it pair down for the CDMA, iPhone? Sure your filter module paired with Skyworks' power modules. What prevented Avago from landing a gas content?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Jacob. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to start today by reviewing some recent business highlights, and then Doug will provide a summary of the third quarter financial results.
As you may have seen from our earnings announcement, revenue for the quarter was at the top end of our guidance at a record $603 million, with net revenue up 8% from last quarter and up 10% year-on-year from third quarter 2010. Interestingly though, each of our target markets performed much as we guided during the course of the third fiscal quarter. 
Now there's little doubt that exist today, uncertainty with regard to the direction of the global economy, the electronics equipment supply chain will undoubtedly be adversely affected, probably has been, by any economic downturn, with semiconductors at the tail end of this chain, which could obviously, have knock-on effects for our business. Nonetheless, we have continued to gain traction with our large OEM customers. And largely as a consequence, we continue to expect to see our business grow through the balance of this fiscal year.
Now let's turn to the results from each of our target markets. Within our wireless communications market, we manufacture, as you may know, FBAR duplexers, power amplifiers, light and proximity sensors and optical navigation devices for feature-rich and smart mobile phones. We also manufacture RF components for the wireless base station market.
Turning to Q3, fiscal Q3, sales from our wireless communications market represented 37% of our third quarter revenues. Our revenue from this target market grew 10% from the preceding quarter and rose 8% above the same quarter last year. This performance was roughly in line with our expectations for the quarter. Growth in Q3 was driven by increased strength in our wireless infrastructure business and by the seasonal growth in handsets, driven particularly by the launch of new LTE and WiMAX smartphones in North America. 
This was offset somewhat by weakness with a large OEM in our optical finger navigation product line. We continue to be encouraged by our momentum, as our parts were designed into 37 new handset platforms during Q3.
I have to add that our -- while it is of interest to note, I should say that our business model in wireless is predicated upon certain handset OEMs pushing for differentiated performance, which we can deliver to our components. Obviously, our success in this segment is based on those OEMs being winners in the marketplace. We believe we have recently been successful with those winners. As a result, we anticipate revenue in this target market will again increase in the high single to low double digits compared to Q3 as those winning OEMs launch their next-generation smartphones.
Turning to wired infrastructure, as you may know too, we design high-speed SerDes, ASICs, and manufacture optical transceivers for enterprise networking, data center switching, and high-speed computing applications. Now revenue from the wired infrastructure market represented 28% of our total Q3 sales. Our sales from the wired infrastructure market grew 6% over Q2 and grew 37% over the same quarter last year. Again, revenues from this target market grew pretty much as we expected at the beginning of the quarter. 
We benefited from strong demand in storage networking, which drove growth in our 8-gigabit and newly introduced 16-gigabit fiber channel solutions in Q3. We've also ramped our 12-channel, 120-gigabit proprietary transceiver modules for supercomputing applications. 
During the same quarter, Q3, we saw strong double-digit growth from our SerDes ASIC business due to strength in next-generation data center switching. Finally, demand was saturated during the quarter by strong orders for proprietary parallel optics sold into core routing applications in China during the same quarter.
Now looking forward to Q4, we believe the Q3 bounce in the core routing business in China will likely recede, but this will be offset by continued strong ASICs SerDes ramp. Accordingly, we expect overall debt revenues from the wired infrastructure market will be flattish for us quarter-on-quarter.
In our industrial and automotive electronics target market, we manufacture and sell optocouplers, and in addition, today, motion encoders and industrial fiber. During Q3, net revenue from this market accounted for 30% of our total revenues. It grew 7% compared to the prior quarter, and grew 5% from the same quarter a year ago.
Now during this Q3, growth came mainly from continued strength in demand in Japan and China. This was offset somewhat by softness in North America and Europe, due largely to supply chain adjustments during the quarter.
All indications however, are that our large industrial OEM customers will continue to grow in this coming Q4. However, we do expect inventory adjustments to continue in the supply chain, particularly among component distributors. Nevertheless, inventory of our parts has remained tight in those channels, and consequently, we expect our industrial revenue to be roughly flat sequentially during Q4. 
Finally, in consumer and computing peripherals, we manufacture, as you know, navigation sensors for optical mice and motion sensors for printers. And revenue from this target market represented only 5% of our third quarter 2011 revenues, and increased 10% from the preceding quarter, but shrunk 34% year-on-year. We muted seasonality expected in this market. We estimate that our Q4 revenue from the consumer side will be roughly flat again as compared to Q3.
So to summarize, 3 basic points. With the volatile and uncertain environment that we currently see, we forecast conservatively that 3 of our 4 target markets, namely: wired, industrial, and consumer, to be roughly flat sequentially in Q4. Secondly, given lean inventory levels in our supply chain, we do not expect to get whipsawed by external adjustments during this quarter. 
And thirdly, [indiscernible] in wireless, we believe we have picked winners, and we are benefiting from the launch of the next-generation smartphones during the quarter, which will drive our growth in our wireless target market. All of this put together leads us to expect revenue in Q4 fiscal '11 to increase between 2% to 5% over last quarter. 
With that summary, let me now turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of third quarter fiscal 2011 financial results.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Hock. Good afternoon, everyone. Before reviewing third quarter fiscal 2011 financial results, I want to remind you that as always, my comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. And as Jacob pointed out, a reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today, and is also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Record revenue of $603 million in Q3 represents an increase of 8% from last quarter and an increase of 10% versus the same quarter a year ago. And as Hock reviewed, the sequential increase was at the top end of our guidance and revenue from each of our target markets came in much as we expected at the beginning of the quarter.
Resales from our distribution partners grew slightly in Q3. At the end of Q3, distribution inventory was at a level consistent with the prior quarter in terms of days on hand. And we continue to keep a very close eye in our supply chain and remain comfortable right now with the level of inventories that we see. And I think Hock has already talked to you about that.
Q3 gross margin was 51.7%. This was consistent with our expectations going into the quarter. Stronger growth in our wireless target market was balanced with growth from our higher margin industrial market to keep gross margin roughly flat quarter-on-quarter. 
During the quarter, R&D expenses increased $8 million sequentially to $81 million. The majority of this increase was from investments that we've made in our Wired and Wireless businesses. SG&A also increased by $4 million to $54 million. Some of the increases in both R&D and SG&A were driven by higher salaries that resulted from our annual review cycle, as well as higher bonus accruals that we made during the quarter. Higher operating profit and design win momentum drove the increase in bonus accruals. Additionally, higher sales pushed commissions up a bit. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 13% and SG&A remained at 9% of net revenue. 
Income from operations increased by $10 million sequentially to $177 million, which is a new record for Avago, and it represented 29% of net revenue. Q3 income from operations compared with income from operations of 167 in Q2 and with 164 in Q3 of last year.
Taxes for Q3 came in lower than guidance at $1 million due to a change in estimate related to the utilization of certain R&D tax credits, the timing of which was driven by the filing of our U.S. federal returns. These results translated into net income of $176 million, which is up 7% from last quarter. Q3 earnings per diluted share of $0.68 compares with $0.64 in Q2, and net income in Q3 of 2010 was $152 million or $0.61 per diluted share. 
Our total share-based compensation in Q3 came in at $11 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q3 includes: $1 million in cost of goods sold; $4 million in R&D; and $6 million in SG&A. In Q4, we anticipate share-based compensation will again be approximately $11 million. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense. So now let me move to the balance sheet.
Days sales outstanding was 43 days. This was down 4 days from the prior quarter. Inventory came in at $200 million, which was up 3% from last quarter in dollar terms. This translated to days on hand of 63 days, which was down 2 days from Q2 and is at the lower end of our inventory model. I think we were pleased with our management of working capital in Q3. 
At the end of the third quarter, our cash balance was $704 million. The primary change in cash came from $211 million in cash provided by operations. Capital expenditures in Q3 was $24 million and that compares with $19 million last quarter. And we expect CapEx in Q4 to be in the range of $35 million to $40 million. The sequential increase will be driven by new mask sets in our ASIC business, as well as capacity additions in our wireless factory. 
With Q4 CapEx in the range I referenced, our full year spend will be very close to the estimate we provided at the beginning of fiscal 2011. On June 30 of 2011, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.09 per ordinary share, which consumed $22 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.01 from the prior quarter. And finally, during Q3, we repurchased and canceled approximately 1.9 million of our ordinary shares, which consumed $68 million of cash. 
Now let me review the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. Revenue is expected to be up 2% to 5% sequentially, driven by anticipated growth in our wireless target market. Gross margin is expected to be 51.5%, plus or minus 75 basis points. This decline is due to the projected growth in our wireless target market. 
Operating expenses are estimated to be $132 million. This was down slightly from Q3. Interest and other is currently expected to be approximately 0. We’re forecasting taxes to be approximately $4 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 256 million shares. And so let me summarize. During Q3, we generated record revenue at the top end of our guidance and maintained margins.
Heading into the fourth quarter, we see growth coming from the ramp of new designs at large OEM customers. And finally, I thought I'd like you know that as we are completing our annual operating plan during the coming quarter, I'll intend to provide an update to our long-term business model during our 2011 fiscal year end conference call, which will be scheduled for early December. 
And that concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, if you will, please open up the call for questions at this time.
