Now you obviously talked about gaining some design wins at large OEMs. So what is the level of conservatism that is built into it given all the concerns that we have about macro demand overall?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Well, I guess the most obvious level of conservatism we try to put in is this: last quarter, if we try to track all our major industrial OEM customers across a range of regions. We're not just tracking one region, we're tracking across-the-board. And if we do that, I would say on weighted average, they grew about 8%, 9% sequentially. The industrial end customers. And we grow 7%. Maybe even slightly below 7%. As I said, for some regions, we were making sure we keep our inventory in our distributors, most of this as part of the distributors under tight control. This quarter, Q4, the same data we looked at what likely grow 3% to 4% sequentially for that, and we are saying we're probably going to be flat. And we have pretty lean inventory in our distribution channel and hopefully the rest of our supply chain out there that would enable us to perform that way. So hopefully, we think we have adjust in some level of uncertainties in this.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then on to gross margins, and a question for Doug, you've had a pretty substantial improvement in revenues over the last few quarters, and it appears that gross margins are kind of flattened about 49% to 49.5% on a GAAP basis. Can you tell us what are some of the key drivers of gross margins? Is it more of a mixed issue or if it's utilization or some combination of?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, Venk, as I've mentioned on a couple of previous calls, what really drives gross margin at Avago is product mix. It's end market to end market, there's differences in gross margin in each of our end markets, and I try to describe in my prepared remarks. Industrial was strong and it offset a little bit of growth in wireless last quarter. And when I look at our guidance for the current quarter, we have growth in wireless, which has gross margin a little below the corporate average, and that is why gross margin is down, call it 20 basis points in the coming quarter. But what drives it quarter-to-quarter and year-on-year is product mix. I think if you look year-on-year, we're still up about 100 basis points or so if I remember the numbers right, which is what we're trying to drive the company to.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Just following up on that question on gross margin, Jacob. As you look forward, I would assume that the wireless business will continue to outperform so that mix will continue to go that way. So just how do you think about that shape of the gross margin as that layers in? Obviously, it's a good problem to have with the growth, but you had talked about 100 basis points per year. And is that still possible given the new mix and obviously, you can perceive some of the slowdowns in the other businesses?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: This is Doug, not Jacob. I'll take the call. Yes, we're not forecasting beyond one quarter at this point. But you have puts and takes in each of the end markets. One thing I would point you to is we're very encouraged by the momentum in the growth in the wired infrastructure end market. Hock mentioned a lot about the ASIC division, as well as some of our proprietary optics. The gross margin profile of the proprietary products in that end market are quite good. And so as those grow, that helps expand gross margin. And countervailing that sometimes in some of the other end markets, you could have growth that is a little bit below. As we look at it over a longer-term horizon, we still feel like we have an ability to expand gross margin.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And just one more, Doug. On the ramp of the 30s it's obviously helping you offset some of this weakness. Can you just talk about where you are in that ramp, as far as timing?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, we're still in the early innings, Blayne. We've talked consistently about a 3-year horizon where we believe we'll be able to double that business. And we're really in the first year of that ramp.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then just maybe one final one on the optical nav.  Any sort of magnitude or color you can give as far as what your expectations obviously, one customer bringing another source, but still you have other customers that you ship to them.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, I mean, you have one customer that's a lot of the business there, and that one customer is potentially down a little bit in the current quarter and that's what we're seeing. And you're right, we have many other customers that buy those devices. But 1 kind of pushes the direction of the business with it all and that's what's going on with OFN.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Hock, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you think the impact of the Japanese earthquake earlier in the year was relative to both the Wireline business where we've actually heard other chip guys talk about customers not being able to procure parts, and also within the industrial business, and if you think it's been additive to industrial, how worried are you about maybe the inventory correction that needs to recur there especially given that you guys are still in and not sell-through?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: For all intents purposes, we're trying to make it as much sell-through as possible too, by the way. But that aside, what the Japanese tsunami and followed by, I guess, the nuclear reactor issue, was my view and you've heard that too from other semi guys and other companies out there when they announce their results. It probably, in fact, I mean more than probably, it did create kind of a bubble of demand, a bubble of orders in the June quarter this year, and which receded and more than receded -- and which probably went the other direction and still going the other direction in this September quarter that we're in, calendar quarter. It's, I guess, pretty normal. What we think is happening is us over ordering in the June quarter because people worried about shortages, component shortages especially, and either backlash this September quarter. So I guess, this kind of behavior, it's more than likely that you will go back up the other direction, maybe to a more muted version of it in the December quarter. I think we're seeing a big part of that happening. Now one may presume that, that could also be due to weak economic performance as well. And that could well be also true. It's hard to break down one from the other. But you have to remember in the September quarter, there's summer seasonality, downward in terms of activity, but also I think the bigger chunk of it is supply chain adjusting, first one way then the other way, and possibly in December another way one more time. And the question for us is to try to see through this all and manage through this all with our distributors. Because the key bottom line is what is end -- just not end resale as much us end demand of our OEM customers that we really focus on.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then, Hock, as my follow-up question, just getting back to LTE on the front-end module front, I'm just kind of curious, I think you talked about 37 phones you're designed into. Where do you think your share will fall out as we look out over the next 6 to 12 months within the LTE ramp? And remind us again of what kind of dollar content per phone we should think about for Avago as LTE handsets really start to ramp next year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: I'm not trying to avoid your question because the fact of the matter is, first and foremost, the dollar content per phone on LTE varies quite dramatically, phone by phone. It depends on whether they use discretes or front-end modules and how many bands they go under each phone carries. Some have much more bands than others. And so that's a big variation. It could range from anywhere from $3 per content, as much as $5, $6. But that aside, main thing is we don't really focus on market share. Our business model is really to get into the sockets where we are either first there, first to market in that particular socket or first into that socket, or that we have a performance differentiation that enables us to win that socket versus anybody else. And I'd be the first to admit, in many cases, we don't have that differentiation and we don't -- we generally don't try to take the business because we are not able to make a price differentiation too, which is not our business financial model. So we don't really track market share. And if you ask me as you did in this question, I don't really know, because I never really tried to look at it that way nor encourage any of my general managers to do likewise.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And maybe I can sneak in one more for Doug, Doug you talked about your belief that you still have opportunities to grow margins over time. Can you kind of walk through the 2 or 3 things that you think are the biggest pressure points in improving gross margins from here?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: What it really comes down to, John, as we've talked consistently about or tried to anyway is growth in incremental revenue from proprietary designs where we believe -- and to us proprietary means sole source designs. And as those become a bigger and bigger percentage of revenue profile here, on average, they have better gross margin than the corporate average in that expands gross margin. That's still very much the story, and as we look at the design wins and the things we're tracking over the next year or 2, we still see a roadmap to be able to continue to do that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: I give you an example, for instance. Our main storage networking. 8 gigabit replaced 4 gigabit, and will soon, you'll see the launch of 16 gigabit. The price of a 16 gigabit today, with a new product launch, is a few times that of an 8 gigabit. Still one part. And so that helps a lot, not just on price but on margin.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vijay Rakesh with Sterne Agee.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: I guess just on the wireless com business, looks like it's going on 15% [ph] year-on-year organically. How do you see that -- as you look at next year on that business, the wireless com side?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Wireless coms next year...

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Wireless Communications, that's hard to figure. We never look that far, hey, it's hard. I guess, we expect -- we like to it to be fairly moderate and grow at about the same percentage year-on-year. Somewhere between 15% and 20% would be nice.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And you mentioned 7 new handset platforms here. Is that into 7 OEMs? How do you break that out?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Vijay, just to clarify, Hock talked about 37 new design wins. And it's with multiple handset OEMs.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brendan Furlong with Miller Tabak.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: On your industrial business, I don't know if you can delineate somewhat between your large customers just signs of industrial rolling over but some factory automation, robotics, your customers like ABB seem to be doing okay. If you can just kind of delineate within your industrial what’s a little bit softer on what's holding you out better?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: By end markets? Interesting. Well, inverters, especially a lot of inverters that go into renewable energy that we all talked about before. Have kind of taken a breather here. Because there's been a slowdown on renewable energy, some of it to do with government subsidies, some of it to do with some technical challenges. So it seems inverters has kind of taken us a bit of a slowdown. On the other side on servo drives, models, we still see fairly strong demand out there, especially on the major, large OEMs, industrial OEMs, servo drives, and guys who sell into models -- who sell motor systems as well, still having a very, very strong -- still in a very strong period. And these are people like Japanese guys and German guys. And then I'm trying to say that because I usually don't try to mention customer names. Then the other side, and finally the last area of factory automation. Factory automation is -- yes, it goes in lumps. There's a lot of that going on especially in the last couple of quarters when there's quite a few factories being built, car factories especially, being built in different locations whether it be China or even Germany, and Eastern Europe. And we've seen very good demand for that. That's probably still better than inverters, but not as strong as servo drives.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then I guess as a follow-up, you mentioned the 16 gigabit storage a couple of minutes ago, I'm just wondering what your -- on that industry transition from 8 to 16? What's your traction there, who do you think your main customers would be? And what's the growth rate looking like for you?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Well, our big claim to fame there is we sell optical transceivers that enable this whole transition. As you know, we've done 2 gigabit years ago. Became 4 gigabit, 8 gigabit, and on the 16 side, no different. We are very much into a lot of traction into that design. It's just starting at the very early start stage of a ramp and adoption. And obviously, [indiscernible] whenever you get on the front end of the curve, it's not the bleeding edge. It is actually a very, very great, profitable and growing business.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sanjay Devgan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Just a quick question on the standard fiber products business. There's been a lot of talk about inventory burns, and that inventory burn in that part of the market. I was wondering if you could give us your sense on how that market is shaping up, where we are in terms of the inventory burn, any color on that would be helpful.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Well, first and foremost, I would like to make a differentiation between enterprise, which is more networking and data centers, computing; and transport, which is more long haul, Metro systems, fiber optic transport, more for telecoms versus enterprise, which is more networking and stuff like that. On the enterprise side, we do not see that much excess inventory in the system at all. I cannot really with any major authority talk to you about the telecoms or transport side because we do not participate much at all in that sector.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Just a follow-up, Hock, you talked about the 37 different design wins on the wireless side. I was wondering if you can give us an update on utilization rates for your core products internally and where you expect that to go next quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Are you referring to factory capacity utilization?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, your internal utilization and how do you expect that to trend as you kind of ramp up these new design wins. And what you feel about your kind of capacity longer term in terms of capability to meet the demand?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Well, we tried to keep our factory running at around 80% is the optimum level, and then we add incremental capacity as we start exceeding 80% to 90%. And ideally, it's in that range. So last quarter, Q3, we are running close to that. This quarter, Q4, normal seasonality. We're probably bring it down somewhat. And don't forget, we're also using outsourcing for our wireless business. So our wireless business makes us also tweak in such a way that we are using quite a bit of outsourcing now too.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aalok Shah with D. A. Davidson.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Hock, one quick question for you. One of your wireless competitors has noted that they're going to be getting some supply of Band 2 solutions, I would assume with BAW filters and with your litigation with TriQuint, how do you view this new competition? Is there reason to believe that they wouldn't be infringing on any of your patents?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Number one, on patent infringement suit, I really am -- I'm not at liberty actually to divulge in much details in it. You know why? Because we're in litigation. And in litigation, we've not only patent infringement, we also have an antitrust suit going on. Sorry about that, but I really am not at liberty to talk much about it. But having said that, I'll point out that, yes, we're aware of a Japanese player providing samples or initial samples of what you call BAW acoustic wave, which is kind of similar technologies as our FBAR filters. But we see that every now and then. I mean, there are other players who have done that before. And you have to keep in mind, we are on probably the ninth or 10th generation of FBAR today. And these people, great engineering skills to do that, and are probably much earlier in the product life cycle development in terms of power generation. And we have probably shipped billions of those units. And that's pretty tough to be able to produce this effectively, efficiently and do that. So this is about market competition too if it really prevails. And we have seen that every now and then from other players out there. And I assume we will continue to see them.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And Doug, just real quickly, I don't want to beat the dead horse, but can you describe the linearity around the July quarter specifically around the industrial and automotive segment? Could you see it a little bit more front-end loaded?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Linearity in industrial specifically, no it wasn't necessarily front-end loaded. It was fairly linear during the quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And do you expect that to be a similar pattern in this quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Hard to tell. I mean, Hock described to you what our booking coverage is, it's around 80% right now. Just looking at how that booking lays out, it's again fairly linear.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rafi Hassan with Jefferies.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: I have a couple of questions, one on FBAR, one on SerDes. Can you provide some color on the revenue mix within wireless in terms of integrated versus discrete components?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: That's a tough question, integrated versus discrete. What you really mean when you say integrated is you mean front-end modules?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Right.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Front-end modules? In the wireless business probably comprise right now at about, no more than about 25%, maybe 30% of our wireless revenues.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Regarding SerDes, last quarter, you mentioned some of your customer inventory levels have been higher. Can you break it down for this quarter? Where did wireline component inventory compared to what you have versus what is out there in the OEM for SerDes and transceivers both?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: I can't really tell you. Our customers literally do not give us that kind of information. If we find it, we have to guess. And it's far for me to want to guess and speculate in this call. So really, we don't have that kind of information that you're asking.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: One last one if I can, what is the typical time delay between your sales of transceivers and end market equipment deployment?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Say that again?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: What is the typical time difference between your sales and the transceiver that gets into the equipment at the end market?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: You're talking about optical transceiver?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Right.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: It varies. It can be as short as 1 week, and it can be as long as 2 months. But typically, it's closer to 1 month or less.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Burton with Kaufman Brothers.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: You just mentioned that approximately 25% are front-end modules. Is that mix-in wireless—is that increasing in the October quarter going forward?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Yes, it's increasing in the October quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And we would expect that to continue to weight out on margins a little bit as we model out? Is that correct, or are we approaching 50% or just kind of a ballpark there?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Again, we don't give specific numbers on specific parts, but you do know FEMs tend to have a little bit lower gross margin because they pull things along at low gross margin.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And to be able to focus it, it's hard to tell. This thing goes up and down quarterly on a fairly volatile manner. I think 30% is about the right level it is at.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then on the OpEx guide, it looks like coming down nicely in the October quarter, is that more on the R&D or SG&A side? And can we start -- not to get too ahead of you, Doug, but can we start using 20% as a long-term target?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Again, I'll give you the long-term target next quarter. We've got one that's out there, and it's R&D 13% to 14% of revenue and SG&A 8% to 9%. It's probably what I'm going to tell you next quarter as well.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: A point that I think you may be trying to understand is part of one reason why it went up, was, as Doug said, is that we accrue for bonuses for the year, and we basically put us true up for about 3 quarters of the year in  Q3. So we won't have to do that in Q4.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: That's why it's guided down next quarter. We had a catch-up in bonus accruals in Q3.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then lastly, for CapEx for FY '12, is that going to be in a similar range as well? And your preferences on use of cash going forward.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: CapEx is kind of 4% to 5% of revenue, and CapEx is always lumpy. It can be up one quarter, down the next. It depends on timing of equipment delivery or new mask sets. So that's kind of what you got going on there. What was the -- use of cash. I think you'll expect to see us continue doing what we have been doing, which is we've had a dividend in place. We've raised it fairly consistently, and the Board, just last quarter, authorized a share buyback program. And we'll assess that quarter by quarter, but I wouldn't expect anything besides that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: First off, the inventory weakness or this weakness you saw on North America and Europe. General economy or is it focused in a particular product and I mean, could you talk about Japan and Asia? I'm just curious about what's causing that trend and how you see it extending out. And then to the BAW filter question earlier, yes, there have been a lot of samples out there, but one of your major competitors has got a lot of excess capacity now in that technology. And I know it's pursuing one of your most lucrative areas, which has been II BAW you dominated. What's included in your guidance for wireless, the non-FEM stuff in terms of pricing? Do you expect pricing to remain firm for your premium parts? Or are you expecting an erosion to accelerate a little bit? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: Let's start with the FBAR or BAW assumption completion. Handset business, we always assume for the same product a certain degree of steady degree of ASP erosion for the product line's life cycle. No surprise as I'm sure for you guys. And we continue to do that. And we typically do that for -- we probably typically see at least anywhere from 3% to 4%, 5%, a quarter of ASP erosion, which we offset with cost reduction on our side, but we expect to see that for the same product going through its product life cycle. So this is no different. And in terms of -- and that's always built in assumptions, but in terms of what does it imply going forward for mix of products, and that's really not -- overall I think we will continue to compete whether is FEMs, front-end modules, or discrete elements, and we'll continue to compete on both sides. And so, I mean, we address it in a fairly long-term manner rather than try to be rather technical and not dropping prices just to keep our market -- keep our competitors in any particular -- or win sockets in any particular socket. So all that stuff, it's not really within the purview or even within the context really our long-term business model. As I said, our long-term business model is to provide products that have price differentiation. So in some -- if our competitor comes with a product that's very similar, we'll try to find a way to make one that is better, performs better. And basically, try to maintain our price premium. And we will continue to do that. That's the call of this company's business model, be it FBAR, fiber optics, optocouplers, any of the products we sell. And SerDes, the same way. That's very, very typical of what we do. It's not about competing on price. Taking that path on the case of industrial, on your question, in Q3, I did remark that we see some softness in Europe and U.S., North America, largely because of inventory adjustment. With distribution, and your question was, is it end demand that's weak versus distribution adjustment? You could be right, it could be a combination of both. But in Q3, which ends July, some part of it falls into the June quarter, as I mentioned earlier, they were typically across-the-board globally in many markets, a small bubble of demand because of the events in Japan. And so you think you go higher. What we have done is we have been very tight in ensuring that we do not -- our distributors do not -- get over shipments of parts from us in that quarter. And that may account for some of the softness we see in North America and Europe. Basically, we do not try to ship to what they specifically want based on what I consider somewhat of an excessive demand because they are concern of shortages. For the same reason in the September quarter, because our inventory is now pretty lean out there, we hope -- we try to ensure that the shipments we make into distributors will reflect the resale that they see with their end customers in all our end markets as well.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: And then to your point that you just made that you don't like to compete on prices and that your performance is usually better or more advanced than your competitors',  which is where you get your proprietary wins, I think it's pretty well-established that one of your big front-end module wins that's ramping in this quarter is this new hybrid device, which is kind of cutting edge to begin with. But there are other competitors out there with even more advanced solutions. I'm sure you've heard with them, whether they're single ended designs or converged devices. And Avago hasn't shown much of that yet, do you see yourself accelerating in some of those products or are you now going to be competing on the converge thing instead of just hybrids or do you just anticipate the market is not going to move to that solution in the long run, so it's not something that you have to worry about in terms of competitive pressure that's obviously, very successful win in 1 of the big smartphone vendors here?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: You know, Ed, we've shown over the last several years that we have been ramping up our Wireless business, and we're very good at managing, in a way, what the market needs. We think so. And we've been very good consistent with that at coming up with products that the market wants, at least key OEMs want. And we've been also very good at differentiating in some of those socket, I won't say all the time, our components such that that's a value-added to those OEMs, those sockets we win. But some we don't. We are unable to differentiate other OEM don't see a value in it and those very often we don't win. And that's fine. But we have been able to sufficiently win enough that we are able to grow our business fairly consistently if you look over the last 4 years. And so I know what you brought up is the latest item what we have faced a lot of those strategic product, the decisions and technology decisions over the last 4 years, and we will, I'm sure, address that also in an appropriate manner.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2011
componenttext: There are no further questions in queue at this time. I would now like to hand the conference back over to Jacob for any closing remarks.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext:
Thank you, Jacob. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to start today by reviewing some of the recent business highlights, and then Doug will provide summary of the fourth quarter and full fiscal year financial results.
Now as you may have seen from our earnings announcement, we had a solid fourth quarter with record revenues and income from operations. Revenue in the fourth quarter of 2011 is up 9% year-on-year from the fourth quarter a year ago. We saw a strong sequential growth in our Wireless Communications business in [indiscernible] and we expected at the beginning of the quarter. This was offset partially by weaker than expected performance from our industrial and consumer end markets.
We believe worldwide volatility in the financial markets and slow growth in China's economy is causing a number of OEMs and most distributors to take risks out of their business models and to substantially reduce their inventory levels. Because of this, we see the impact of lower component demand in our industrial markets. In contrast, however, we also experience certain phenomena that leads our revenues in this period of demand uncertainty. 
In particular, certain wireless OEM winners in the marketplace have been able to grow force. Additionally, in wired networking, investments in core routing and data centers remain strong, very much to our benefit in SerDes and fiber. The recent and ongoing flooding in Thailand is having an impact on varied semiconductor and optical supply chains. While the impact on our own business was small in Q4, we expect revenue could be negatively impacting the range of $10 million to $20 million in Q1.
Certain multimarket wireless and industrial products were being tested, assembled with a contract manufacturer based in the flood zone. Most facilities there have been shut down as a result. We are in the process of moving equipment and qualifying new contract manufacturers to bring the manufacturing of these products back online, and we expect this work to be substantially completed during the course of Q1.
With that, let me turn to results from each of our target markets. Within wireless, we manufacture our bond, as you may know, duplexers, power amplifiers, light and proximity sensors and optical single navigations for smartphones and feature-reach phones. We also manufacture RF components for wireless base stations and wireless infrastructure markets. Sales from our wireless communications target market represented 42% of our fourth quarter revenue, and our revenue from this target market grew 16% compared to Q3 and 18% compared to a year ago. This performance was stronger than our expectations for the quarter. Growth in Q4 was driven largely by strength in our power amplifier business driven by the launch of new smartphones.
Our cutting-edge Multi-mode Multi-band Power Amplifiers continue to ramp very successfully. Looking ahead to first quarter fiscal '12, the quarter we are in right now, we expect overall wireless revenues to decline on a percentage basis in the low double digits compared to Q4. In line with normal seasonality, we expect the RF portion of this business to be down by high single digits, exacerbated by weakness in our OFN Optical Finger Navigation business.
Next, within wired infrastructure, as you may know, too, we design high-speed SerDes ASICs and manufacture optical or fiber optic transceivers for enterprise networking data center switching and high-speed computing applications. Revenue from the wired infrastructure market represented 28% of our total Q4 sales. In Q4, our sales from this wired infrastructure market grew 4% over Q3 and grew 24% over Q4 2010. 
In fact, this business has been our steady-eddie. Revenues from the wired infrastructure market grew slightly better than we expected at the beginning of the quarter. We benefited from strong double-digit growth from our SerDes ASIC business during the quarter due to the ramp of new customer programs in Nexus switches and the MX edge routers as well as new design wins in ASICs. 
Looking forward to Q1, we expect overall revenues from wired target -- wired infrastructure target market to decline high single digits quarter-on-quarter. After a strong quarter in Q4, we believe we expect a chase spending on core routing programs, which tend to be lumpy, appear to be slowing this quarter especially for proprietary 5 gigabit per second fiber optics.
Turning to industrial and automotive electronics target market, we manufacture and sell optocouplers, motion encoders and industrial fiber. Net revenue from this market accounted for 26% of our Q4 2011 net revenue. Net revenue -- net sales from this end market declined 10% compared to the prior quarter and declined 6% from the same quarter a year ago.
Worse than expected weakness during the quarter came mainly from slower sales of our optocouplers and motion encoders. We believe this was driven by slow economic growth in China and a slowdown in -- particularly a slowdown in the renewable energy sector, which triggered OEMs and distributors to contract their supply chain. We experienced this particularly in Europe and Asia-Pacific within the servo drives and inverter segments. We expect a continued supply chain contraction exacerbated in Q1 by the ongoing flooding in Thailand will lead to revenue from the industrial market to be down low to mid single-digit this quarter.
Finally, in consumer and computing peripherals, we manufacture, as you know, tagged navigation sensors for optical mice and motion sensors for printers. Revenue from this target market represented only 4% of our fourth quarter 2011 sales, and revenues from this market decreased 18% from last quarter and have shrunk 31% on a year-on-year basis. We continue to see muted demand here.
In summary, Q4 revenue growth from smartphones and wired infrastructure more than offset weakness in industrial and consumer, allowing us to show slight overall revenue growth for the quarter. In Q1, we see all our end markets declining and believe revenue would decrease between 10% and 14% as compared to Q4. Now you realize here our OEM revenue really has not been the problem. It will only decline single digit as is the case normally seasonally. But supply chain contractions, particularly industrial, are magnified by distributors as we substantially lower our revenue into the distribution channel this quarter.
Just stepping back, as we aim 2011 fiscal year, Avago, we believe, we see that Avago has achieved a number of milestones we set for ourselves. December 2010, we completed buyback of remaining senior subordinated notes, leaving the company essentially debt-free through the year. In the same month, we initiated a dividend for shareholders starting at $0.07 a share. We have increased this dividend each quarter in the fiscal year and paid $0.11 per share by the quarter ending September 30, 2011.
Power optics are an exciting growth area for Avago. It is also a proprietary area, a product area for us. And in November 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals affirm the strength of our intellectual property around this technology. The decision include our proprietary embedded technologies as well as our industry standard field pluggable phone factors, and we remain very committed to protecting and enforcing our patent and intellectual property rights here.
Also, over the course of the fiscal year, our private equity ownership of Avago declined from approximately 60% to approximately 10% through 5 public offerings of our shares. And finally, by growing revenues 12% year-on-year, we achieved the top end of our revenue model. And additionally, we grew non-GAAP gross margin by 260 basis points year-on-year.
Later in this call, Doug will provide an update to our financial model. Our goal is to grow revenue 10% to 12% annually to expand growth of product margins and to leverage our infrastructure to expand our operating margin on an annual basis. To support the anticipated growth of our proprietary products, especially in Multi-mode Power Amplifiers, we expect to expand our manufacturing processes in Fort Collins, Colorado. A side benefit of making of this front end manufacturing investment is an expected improvement in gross margins for our wireless business in the years ahead. We do expect capital expenditures to increase, however, in fiscal 2012 to approximately $200 million from $112 million in fiscal 2011.
With that quick summary, let me now turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of fourth quarter and fiscal 2011 financial results.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Hock. Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for joining the call. Before reviewing the fourth quarter and fiscal 2011 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today, as always, will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today and is also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Record revenue of $623 million in Q4 represents an increase of 3% from last quarter and an increase of 9% versus the same quarter a year ago. And as Hock reviewed, the sequential increase was in line with our guidance. However, revenue from our wireless and wired target market came in better than we expected, and revenue from our industrial and consumer target markets came in worse than we expected.
Resales from our distribution partners declined in Q4 relative to Q3, while our distribution inventory rose somewhat. This put us at the end of the quarter at the higher end of our desired distribution inventory model. And as Hock alluded to, we expect this inventory level will be down in Q1. I would point out, somewhat fortuitously, the uptick in inventory is mitigating the impact from the Thai supply disruption. And just a final comment on disti; we have not seen resales begin to grow again, the decline that we saw during Q4 seems to have stabilized at this lower level.
Q4 gross margin was 51.2%. This was down from last quarter and slightly below the midpoint of our guidance. The biggest driver of the sequential decline in gross margin was lower revenue from our high-margin industrial end market and higher revenue from our lower margin wireless end market. During the quarter, R&D expenses decreased $2 million sequentially to $79 million. SG&A also decreased this by $5 million to $49 million. 
The decreases in R&D and SG&A were driven by lower variable compensation as well as tight control of discretionary spending. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 13%, while SG&A declined to 8% of net revenue. Income from operations increased by $14 million sequentially to $191 million, which was a new record for Avago and represented 31% of net revenue. Q4 income from operations compares with income from operations of $177 million in Q3 and with $171 million in Q4 of last year.
Taxes for Q4 were slightly higher than guidance at $5 million due to the jurisdictional mix of income. These results translate into net income of $186 million, which is up 6% from last quarter. Q4 earnings per diluted share of $0.73 compares with $0.68 in Q3. Net income in Q4 of 2010 was $190 million or $0.76 per diluted share. And I should just remind you, from a year ago, Q4 2010 net income benefited from a $29 million discrete tax benefit, which was roughly $0.11 per diluted share, which resulted from the redemption of our senior subordinated notes.
Total share-based compensation in Q4 was $11 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q4 excludes $1 million in cost of goods sold, $4 million in R&D and $6 million in SG&A. In Q1, I anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $12 million. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense. 
Let me now move to the balance sheet. Days sales outstanding was 48 days. This was up 5 days from the prior quarter, primarily due to the linearity of revenue in Q4. Inventory came in at $194 million, which was down 3% from last quarter. This translated to days on hand of 58 days, which was down 5 days from Q3 and is below our inventory model. I do think it's possible that inventory could grow slightly next quarter. 
At the end of the fourth quarter, our cash balance was $829 million. The primary change in cash came from $195 million of cash that was provided by operations. And I wanted to just foreshadow Q1 for you a little bit here. Q1 is generally our weakest quarter for cash generation due to the seasonally lower revenues as well as the payment of annual employee bonuses that relate to the prior fiscal year.
CapEx in Q4 was $37 million, which was in line with our expectations for the quarter. We expect CapEx in Q1 to be in the range of $40 million to $45 million. As Hock referred or as Hock referenced, approximately $200 million for the full year is our CapEx expectation. The sequential increase will primarily be driven by capacity additions in our wireless factory, as well as additional spending, to bring alternative contract manufacturers online in response to the flooding in Thailand.
At September 30 of 2011, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.11 per share. This consumed $27 million of cash. This dividend was raised $0.02 from the prior quarter. And finally, during Q4, we repurchased and canceled approximately 750,000 shares, which consumed $25 million of cash. And as it was yearend, let me briefly recap our fiscal 2011 full year results. Revenue increased by 12% to approximately $2.3 billion. Gross margin improved by 260 basis points to 51.7% as compared to 49.1% for fiscal 2010. Net income for fiscal 2011 increased to $692 million or $2.70 per diluted share as compared to $547 million or $2.19 per diluted share in fiscal 2010.
Let me now review the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the first quarter of fiscal 2012. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. 
Revenue is expected to decline 10% to 14% sequentially. This is driven by wireless seasonality, the general industry slowdown as well as supply challenges from the flooding in Thailand. Gross margin is expected to be 50.5% plus or minus 100 basis points. This decline is due to anticipated product mix shifts, particularly within the wireless end market. 
Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $125 million and forecasting interest and other to be approximately negative $1 million due to currency impacts from yen-based foreign exchange liabilities. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $4 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 254,000,000 shares.
Finally, let me review the medium-term business model for Avago, which I said I would update you on during the Q3 earnings call.
While this is not intended to represent annual guidance, this is the non-GAAP model that we manage the business to. Our goal is to grow revenue at an annual pace of approximately 10% to 12%. Our desire is to have gross margin in the range of 50% to 53%. We are targeting R&D to be approximately 14% of net revenue. We targeting SG&A to be approximately 8% of net revenue. And consequently, if you do the math, our goal is to have operating margins in the range of 28% to 31% of net revenue. And finally, I expect taxes to remain in the range of 3% to 4% of operating income.
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, at this time, would you please open up the call for questions?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. The first one, just a clarification. When you gave the segment guidance for the fiscal first quarter, did you guide the Industrial business down single digits or low double digits?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Single digits, mid to high single.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Oh mid to high, not mid to low, okay. So kind of down 8% to 10%, got it. Beyond that then, a more substantive question, the CapEx guidance increasing for the wireless business, is that something that you have visibility in the design wins for that? Is it kind of a cost driver or revenue driver? What's leading to that decision?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Well, again, it's combination of reasons, Ross, one of which is we're improving our -- into a much better improved process for gallium arsenide. And a lot improving process is a very engineering intensive and rather proprietary approach that we chose to take. And so we decided to bill it ourselves. Secondly is right now we're completely outsourced on our gallium arsenide products. Our demand for our products is growing. And we figured that it's a good way to outsource it and at the same time do it internally. The side benefit of that is, naturally, we would have an improvement in gross margin as we go into production with a mix of internal and external sourcing, all those reasons.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Ross, this is Doug. Let me just clarify. I think I said mid to high industrial. It was actually low to mid single digits on the industrial guidance. Sorry about that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Got you. And then I guess the one quick follow-up, the flood impact, $10 million to $20 million in your guidance, how should we think about that snapping back if, in fact, it will?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Well, I would certainly believe that it will snap back probably in Q2. Not so -- the way we are planning it, anticipating it in our guidance is that it will have that $10 million to $20 million impact on revenues for Q1. But you would certainly -- so that would result in us shipping below what we otherwise could have shipped in natural demand. But in Q2, I would expect Q2 to pick up a lot of that slack.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Terence Whalen with Citi.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: This one is on the industrial end market. It seems like after a 10% decline in October, you're expecting that decline to mitigate to low to mid single-digit in January. What about beyond that? Based on current consumption levels that you see, can you help us understand if you would expect industrial seasonality to improve in April? I'm trying to understand the difference between the consumption levels and the inventory changes and how that's affecting that revenue.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: All right. As you can gather, most of our industrial business go through distributors. And as you also know, we recognize revenue on a shipping basis into the distributors. And the interesting thing we see in this whole process is that a resale, which is the end demander of distributors, see, as Doug pointed out in his remarks, kind of flatted out in this quarter. Q1 has gone -- is pretty much flattened out. However, on a shipping basis to our distributors, we continue to bring down revenues particularly. And part of the reason for that is one -- is the fact that, one, related to the Thai flooding where a lot of industrial products are affected. We had brought in products to mitigate that flooding impact in Q4 but 2, is also our ability to ship has been reduced in this quarter. So we'll be shipping less of the -- bottom line is we are shipping in the distributors less of our products than likely we are reselling in Q1.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then the second question is on some of the commentary around the wireless business. I think you made the comment, Hock, that you would expect, based on adding some of the in-house gallium arsenide capacity, you'd expect the gross margin profile of that business to improve. Can you help us understand, when you're making that comment, are you talking about you expect the mix of MMPA to just regular PAs to improve? Or are you also making a comment about FBAR content increasing as well?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay. No, I was referring specifically to power amplifiers, PAs. Whether it's MMPAs or discrete PAs, it's related to PAs. And by the way, so you guys don't get too excited upfront. This capacity expansion takes a while, and we do not really see the impact of that margin improvement until 2013. Maybe late 2012 but definitely and largely in 2013.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays Capital.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the wireless guidance. I mean, you still should have some customers that are ramping, so maybe you can talk about how maybe some of the ramps of more successful phones are impacting some of your other customers. And then with the OFN business, is there -- are you seeing some share loss? Or is this really just demand from the customer?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay. Let me take the -- your second question first. On OFN, we don't believe we have seen any significant share loss. It's related to the fact that we're right in our inventory in the pipeline in the supply chain of customers, particularly one major customer. And that's the main reason for the weakness or the softness or the reduction, I should say, sequentially of our OFN revenue. We don't think there's any significant impact on our share at all in so far as OFN is concerned. In respect to your first question, I'm sorry about that, Blayne, but it's really not our policy or practice to name customers in this public forum, sorry.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: No, I was not looking for you to name customers. I guess I was just wondering if you could provide some color. Are you seeing -- some of your customers see some weakness due to share loss. And I'm just trying to reconcile.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay. And you would not -- I assume -- I hope you -- and I assume it will not surprise the audience and you too, Blayne, is that, yes, in -- as in any other end market, in the handset market, in particular, there are multiple, there are several players. And we have seen over the years a continual change adjustment in shares as one player comes up with a new phone that look -- that is much more popular than another. And we continue to see that. And in particular, this recent quarter or so, we have seen that very, very much so. As new generation of smartphones launch, there's a lot of features coming, including LTE, WiMAX and other stuff. So, yes, we continue to see those adjustments in market share among our customers, and those changes are very dynamic.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Lipacis with Jefferies.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Doug, for you, I think you mentioned that the distributor inventories were higher than you -- than normal. Could you quantify that at all? Where are they now? What's normal? Can you talk about where they were in the financial crisis?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: I haven't really had a practice of quantifying it numerically. I think all I'd tell you, Mark, is that they were up and at the higher end. We've got to model for where we'd like to see them. And when we exited Q4, they were at the higher end of that model. And so we're bringing it down in Q1. I don't want to get into the habit of quantifying it numerically, though.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And, Hock, I think, correct me if I'm wrong. I may have misheard you. Did you talk about beyond distributors that a desire to lower inventories at OEMs or beyond the distributors? Or were you just talking about demand contraction?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Well, I really made a mess of that, did I? Okay, let me try to clarify that. No, what I did say, a couple of points I did try to indicate is it's interesting to know that over the past 12 months in fiscal '11, our OEM demand has been very consistently sequentially up from the beginning of Q1 all the way up to this past recent Q4. Our OEM demand, OEM revenue, has been sequentially up all the way through. And even in Q1 where we're guiding a normal seasonal downturn, we see only a very relative, a normal seasonal downturn with respect to our OEM business. In contrast of that in our distributor side, revenue has been rather all over the map. But more than not is, especially since the middle of fiscal '11, we've seen the revenues into our distributors. And resale from our distributors obviously declined and a rollover, in fact, and start to decline. And the decline accelerated particularly in our fiscal Q4 on resale and our revenue, too. And our resale from distributors will be almost flattish from Q4 and Q1. But in terms of adjusting our inventory in our distributors, we will continue in this guidance in our forecast to continue to ship less into our distributors and that's why our distributor revenue in Q1 will be down significantly from Q4.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: I think you mentioned about the $10 million to $20 million impact from the Thai flood. Is that specific to the industrial segment? And if it is, excluding that, it appears that the industrial segment is sort of holding flattish. So the question is, is that the right way to look at that impact? And if it is, then are you being conservative enough with your guidance on the industrial side?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: We think we're being realistic in our guidance. I knew -- you correctly looked at it, yes.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Yes, Vivek, it's primarily industrial. There is some multimarket wireless in there, but a lot of it is industrial.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Got it. And then the trajectory of OpEx, I know you're taking it down a bit in Q1. How should we look at the trajectory for the remainder of the year? Does it snap back as quickly also? Is Q1 the new level? Or how should we look at it?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: I don't know, Vivek. A lot of the variation quarter-to-quarter in OpEx is driven by variable compensation and so business levels grow. The spending will grow. And if business levels don't grow, the spending will be relatively constant. In a more medium-term level, I would refer you back to that business model that I described. We do have an inclination right now to try to spend a little bit more as a percent of revenue on R&D. That helps us grow the business over the medium to longer term. So we are kind of looking at incremental R&D programs, but we're being very cautious right now.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Got it. And just one last one, if I may. Do you think OFN is still a growth business for you given that one of the larger customers for that is facing some market share issues?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: It's probably not a growth business, Vivek. It will hang in there for a while, but I don't think it's going to grow all that much.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Venk Nathamuni with JPMorgan.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Hock, on the last earnings call, you talked about 37 models in which you have some design wins, especially on the 4G and LTE phones. Where do you expect the ramp for those phones to occur in terms of the timing? And also, do you expect that to offset some of the seasonal slowdown in your hardware wireless business?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Well, I guess most of -- to answer your first part, most of these 37 phones, some of them have launched, the rest are yet to happen and probably will happen through the first half of calendar 2012, the rest of them. And some of them already start to happen, and it's helping obviously cushion this seasonal downturn, typical seasonal downturn, in wireless in this current Q1 quarter. But we will still -- we believe, we'll still see this seasonal downturn for Q1. It's pretty much expected. We have seen that for the last couple of years in Q1. But thereafter, Q2 onwards, we do expect sequential growth in our wireless revenues through the rest of fiscal '12.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up for Doug, Doug, where do you think margins can trough for the current cycle? Especially, what was your decision rate? And given that the last time your revenue was in the $550 million range, which is kind of the midpoint of guidance that you've given for next quarter, but how should we think about gross margins beyond the current quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Yes, Venk, I don't like to give specific numbers beyond the current quarter. I gave you the longer-term model of $50 million to $53 million. So one would think, if that's how we're trying to manage the business, we hope we're at the low point, lowish point. From a year ago, our gross margin, if you go to the midpoint of the guidance for Q1, if you looked at Q1 last year, gross margin was actually a little bit higher. And the phenomena in there is our industrial business is down from where it was a year ago, and that is our highest margin business. So that's kind of what's going on relative to where we were at revenue levels at this point, before.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up on the question on utilization, where they were last quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Yes, utilization was kind of in the 70, mid-70s range, Venk. And it'll be down a bit in Q1 as we're seasonally down in wireless.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Romit Shah with Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011

They're talking about converged PAs, converged solutions. I was wondering if you can discuss that, give us a little color on your roadmap and your thoughts in general about converged solutions.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: I see. Well, I mean, this is -- frankly, this just could -- I know some of our competitors use that term. And I'll be honest as I am not even 100% sure what they mean by that. I mean, what you have now, we call it multiband multimode. In some ways, it's -- a converged PA might be a subset of that. It's -- the whole concept is, as you need more and more interfaces, 3G or UMTS, multiple bands, LTE add-on for the bands, bands being different parts of the frequency, you basically, theoretically, you have a duplexer and a PA for every band. And you never get away from duplexers, one duplexer per band. But in the case of power amplifiers, technology and the ways you think at design and process, you may be able to get away with sharing power amplifiers among bands. And I don't know if that's what people mean. But really, by sharing single power amplifier among a few bands, that's really what they mean -- what we mean by multiband multimode PAs, and maybe that's what somebody else mean by converged PAs. But I'm not really sure what they mean, but from our point of view, we don't use that term. We call it multimode multiband PAs, which is really using one or more PAs to share multiple bands.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2011
componenttext: Interesting question, Terence. And, yes, here is with our thinking long term of the wireless RF component business source. And as you know, we supply both FBAR duplexers, the filter that is, as well as the power amplifiers now. And where we see is you're right. More and more of the growth, if you look at smartphone growth as opposed to total handset growth, more and more smartphone growth will be coming from emerging countries like China where -- and even parts -- certain parts of Europe, but definitely China emerging countries where smartphones are lower or lesser penetrated, so that will be one sector of it. Having said that, one other interesting thing we find in this wireless handset market or smartphone market is it pushes, constantly pushes, the envelope in next-generation as we see from 3G to 4G LTE or 4G, as we call it, and will be next 4.5, 5G. And as each -- what it implies is more and more bands out there. And more than more and more bands out there, more and more roaming from different countries come in, which basically require every phone, every hand smartphones to have more and more RF content. So what we see is another situation where these developed countries or emerging countries and particularly so in developed countries where the content of the RF content of smartphone increases fairly rapidly. As I mentioned earlier, one band requires in theory one duplexer, discrete duplexer, and one PA. You can integrate the PA, the power amplifiers, so that they share across bands, but duplexers, much, much harder, in fact, impossible. So the duplexer content will definitely grow very linearly with the complexity of smartphones as we move to higher wireless bandwidth over time. Power amplifiers may not grow as linearly but still the content will increase. And so far, as we see this smartphone market as an extremely interesting opportunity that will continue to grow very, very well for us.
